alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for employees' club fees
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers covering the cost of club fees for employees
title: Expenses and benefits: club membership

table.body:
As an employer covering the cost of club membership for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

What you have to report and pay depends on who arranges the membership, and who pays the club.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don't have to pay or report anything to HMRC if both the following apply:

- you arrange your employee's membership and pay the club directly
- the employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or less a year


*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the club membership isn't [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-club-membership/whats-exempt "exempt"), you must report it to HMRC, and you may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance. 

This depends on who arranges the membership and who pays the club.

##If you pay fees for an employee

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or directors, report the amount you pay on form P11D, section M and pay Class 1A National Insurance.

##If your employee arranges membership but you pay the fees

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section B | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Directors | Report on form P11D, section B | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll 


##If your employee pays fees but you reimburse them 

This counts as earnings. Add the amount to your employee's other earnings, and deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll.  

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
